Thus, the most current version RMP/PSM and related documents and elements maintained onsite may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to EPA and other regulatory agencies. 

During the most recent PHA, the team identified items that they hope will further improve safety at the facility. Refer to the master tracking log for the responsible individual, estimated and actual completion dates, status, etc.

rgency response are similar, regardless of the hazard. However, the Plan contains certain hazard-specific information in cases where the hazard requires a response that is unique and not covered by other elements of the Plan. 

Super Store Industries has implemented an Emergency Response Team that is trained to respond offensively to ammonia releases. All refrigeration operators are HAZWOPER Technician Level trained. The Super Store Industries Emergency Response Plan is designed to meet the regulatory requirements and give our employees and community the maximum protection in the event of an ammonia release. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

Employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns at this facility. Several PHA studies have been conducted at Super Store Industries and each time the study team made recommendations for additional safety. 

Super Store Industries will respond to all suggested mitigation measures promptly. Super Store Industries has established completion schedules for proposed actions either within the allotted time frame given by regulation or based on the timetable agreed upon between the facility and San Joaquin County CUPA. Management responses and support will be consistent with Super Store Industries commitment to safe and environmentally responsible operations. 

Super Store Industries recognizes that the RMP / PSM is performance based and has processes in place to ensure the program is a living document. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Super Store Industries continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. Super Store Industries will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the RMP/PSM, related attachments, and program elements will b

n program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities. 

All Super Store Industries employees receive ammonia awareness training and their responsibilities within the Emergency Response Plan. Additionally, they have access to the complete RMP / PSM, the IIPP and more for review, comment, and input. Together these activities improve the overall safety of the employees, environment, and the surrounding community. 

 Compliance Audit 
The audit process is a valuable tool to confirm Super Store Industries compliance with the RMP / PSM program and whether each of the elements in the prevention program has been implemented and properly documented. Super Store Industries has established a Management System to address any shortcomings which the audit may find. A priority list is developed, and target dates are set for any changes or corrections. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 
An investigation into the Super Store Industries' Lathrop facility accident history revealed that there have been no releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds over the past five years (May 2019  May 2024). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
This Emergency Action and Response Plan, otherwise referred to as the EARP or the Plan, has been developed to ensure adequate preparedness with rapid and appropriate response to emergency situations. The purpose of this Plan is to protect Super Store Industries (SSI) employees, contractors, visitors, the environment, and assets. 

This Plan was designed to be applicable to those types of emergencies that may affect SSI and provides an organizational and procedural framework for the management of emergency incidents. The Plan also describes the coordination of SSI and outside agencies to further protect SSI employees and property, as well as the surrounding community and environment. 

The Plan is based on the concept that the elements of eme

ufacturers OEM manual may be used for reference. The standard operating procedures are periodically reviewed to ensure they reflect the current operating practices and certified to such annually. 

 Mechanical Integrity 
Prevention is the primary reason regular and scheduled inspection, testing, and maintenance is performed on the Super Store Industries refrigeration system. The system shall follow manufacturer recommendations, industry RAGAGEP, and/or industry practice to help maintain the system. The facility utilizes a mix of authorized and trained personnel and outside contractors to perform routine and emergency maintenance on the system. 

 Incident Investigation 
Written procedures and forms are in place detailing how and when the facility must investigate releases. Super Store Industries investigates releases and near misses that could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia. Recommendations are addressed and corrected by facility management. Reports are kept for five years. 

 Training 
Super Store Industries certifies operators following completion of operator training and confirmation of the operator's ability to apply what they have learned. Refrigeration operators are given initial training on hazards of anhydrous ammonia, an overview of the Super Store Industries refrigeration system, and emergency operations to name a few. To ensure compliance with the procedures, refresher training is conducted as required. Where possible, training utilizes direct experience in the field to facilitate task understanding and address multiple learning methods. 

 Employee Participation 
Super Store Industries employees help to improve and maintain the prevention program in multiple ways. Refrigeration operators participate in the process hazard analysis by providing system expertise. Refrigeration operators help develop operating procedures as well as ensure they reflect the true operating instruction. This involvement encourages ownership of the preventio

ntenance activities. New equipment data is requested through the MOC process and is part of the contactors package upon installation. 

The facility has also worked to further develop the information pertaining to the equipment in the covered process. Such review and revisions include an updated and detailed list of safety systems. The P&IDs are currently being reviewed, field verified, and corrections are redlined. 

 Process Hazard Analysis 
Provide thorough team analysis of the Super Store Industries refrigeration system. The team analysis such scenarios as an overpressure situation, high and/or lower pressures or temperatures, corrosion, equipment failure, equipment siting, emergency situations and human factors. The types of natural and human caused external events considered in the process hazard analysis include: 
 earthquake, tornado, extreme severe weather, flood 
 inadequate physical security devices (locks, lighting, fences) may lead to outside threats which may lead to an anhydrous ammonia leak 
 lack of security awareness training for employees to help identify internal threats 
 lack of workplace violence policy and/or procedures could lead to a potential anhydrous ammonia release 
 anhydrous ammonia theft from equipment that is outside and not monitored 
 a suspicious package is delivered with the intent to cause an anhydrous ammonia release 
 a bomb threat that could cause an ammonia release 

All recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by facility management. A priority list is developed, and target dates are set for the recommendations to reduce or eliminate hazards. 

 Operating Procedures 
Written procedures and policies are in place that establish how the refrigeration system is operated and maintained. Super Store Industries has developed standard operating procedures for the required operating phases such as the safe and normal operation and shutdown of the Super Store Industries refrigeration system. The man

is situated off McKinley Avenue and Louise Avenue. The area is primarily industrial with a new apartment complex currently being built to the East of the facility. The facility chills and stores a variety of food products in the cold storage warehouse. The facility also manufactures ice. 

Super Store Industries Lathrop uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant within the facilitys refrigeration system. The systems, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycle ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) to provide refrigeration for cold storage rooms and ice manufacturing. Changes in pressure are directly related to changes in temperature. For example, lowering the ammonia pressure lowers its temperature. Low pressure (cold) liquid ammonia provides refrigeration by removing ambient heat. Removal of ambient heat causes the liquid ammonia (contained within the system) to vaporize. 

Heat is later removed from the ammonia as it is condensed back into a liquid. Typical operating conditions range from 0 - 6 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 100-160 psig on the high side. The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases. Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Super Store Industries prevention program is described in the PSM program. The prevention program implemented by Super Store Industries is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs. 

Key objectives of Super Store Industries prevention program are briefly described below: 

 Process Safety Information 
Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical and equipment information. The facility has worked to locate and keep on file the original manufacturer OEM manuals, material of construction, equipment drawings, etc. for reference purposes and to aid in mai

The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. This process does not meet the requirements of Program 1. The process is subject to OSHAs PSM standard. Therefore, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance. This program was developed to satisfy San Joaquin Countys request for a site specific RMP program. The following areas are addressed in this summary: 

1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source 
2. The stationary source and regulated substances handled 
3. The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures 
4. The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps 
5. The five-year accident history 
6. The emergency response program 
7. Planned changes to improve safety 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

The Super Store Industries Lathrop facility abides by the emergency response procedures and policies detailed in the Emergency Response Plan manual. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: - To save lives. - To minimize and avoid injuries. - To protect the environment. - To minimize property damage. Super Store Industries maintains an emergency response team whose members are trained to the HAZWOPER Technician level. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes. 

STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
